Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content:
For anyone who is running or wants to run a WooCommerce store, I've added Komodo support to VerusPay and the new release (v0.3.1) is now available! This is a very different kind of payment gateway, it is "self-sovereign" which means you own the gateway, there is no third party, you host your own wallet(s) and your store becomes a full native node! (or your wallet server does, which is the recommended setup).

If you'd like to check it out and setup a store or try it on your existing store, you can follow the setup guide here: https://veruspay.io/setup

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: Supported coins so far: Verus, Pirate, Komodo

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: More coming soooonnnnn - I think this is the first payment "gateway" of its kind, it's essentially a blockchain-integrated tool allowing you to have full ownership over the entire process.  Source code can be accessed at https://github.com/veruscoin/veruspay and the plugin is in the WordPress library (but you'll want to follow the setup guide above to install).

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content:
The most prominent player right now is Komodo with their Delayed Proof of Work (DPoW).

The system is an atypical Delegated Proof of Stake implementation with 64 notary nodes. The nodes do not need to hold any KMD, however they get voted once a year into ‚Äúnotarizing‚Äù by KMD holders. The node owners are rewarded by block rewards from KMD inflation. Much more info here.

The nodes write the newest block headers from KMD into the Bitcoin blockchain. This way, KMD always has a fallback to the state of its chain in case of an attack, inside the BTC blockchain.

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content:
Delegated Proof of Stake is a system which brings a fair amount of politics and centralization into the blockchain governance. It is fairly controversial due to holder concentration and the implications on the policies voted into existence. This is especially concerning considering the start of KMD as a Bitcoin Dark (BTCD) ICO, which was afterwards exit pumped.

Any coin that wishes to be protected by KMD‚Äôs DPoW has to request this from the KMD team. It is a permissioned product. The implementation fee is paid to the KMD developers. This is a centralized process. The users of KMD blockchain nor notary nodes have no say in which coins are protected by DPoW.

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content:
The coins that are protected by DPoW save their block headers using the OP_RETURN command onto the KMD blockchain, similar to the Veriblock solution.

The chains which currently protect themselves using KMD‚Äôs DPoW are GAME, EMC2, GIN and other smaller networks.

To successfully attack a blockchain protected by DPoW, the attacker would also have to revert blocks also on the Bitcoin blockchain on top of the attacked altcoin chain, which is unfeasible. The solution in theory prevents all types of 51% attacks that have been explored so far.

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content: DPoW is therefore currently the best available product for projects with minor hashpower or chain security fears. Main concerns come with the underlying assets history (KMD) and the permissioned implementation.

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content: KMD  -----  51% attack "protection-as-a-service"

Author: coinmonks || CoinCodeCap#8469
Content: https://medium.com/@ambroidcrypto/51-attack-protection-comparison-591b4a7c500f
